authorsByline: amykup, Amy Kuperinsky | akuperinsky@njadvancemedia.com, Amy Kuperinsky
title: See Emmy winner Eric André in N.J. filming car accident for ‘Little Brother’ movie with John Cena
description: The comedy is just one of a series of Netflix movies that have filmed in New Jersey this summer.
content:
Eric André filming the movie "Little Brother" in Madison Friday. Bobby Bank | GC Images

Eric André was cruising in a blue Chevy Spark Friday in New Jersey, destined to crash.

He was filming scenes for the upcoming Netflix movie “Little Brother” in Madison.

André stars with John Cena in the comedy, which has been filming across New Jersey this summer.

The actor and comedian, who won an Emmy last year for hosting Adult Swim’s long-running series “The Eric André Show,” plays the titular chaotic little brother to John Cena’s real estate agent character in the movie.

In Friday’s scenes, filmed at Greenwood Avenue and Brittin Street in Madison, André and the hatchback car are involved in a T-bone collision.

READ MORE: John Cena and Eric André filming ‘Little Brother’ movie in N.J.

On set, André’s character could be seen not paying attention to the road while driving and yelling out to a group of people on the street.

The Chevy had a taped-up window and the back of the car was covered in bumper stickers with messages like “Exotic Princess,” “How Is My Driving? Do You Have Any Sardines? Will You Share Some If I Pull Over?” and some X-rated phrases.

“My other ride is a zamboni,” the license plate frame proclaimed.

André, 42, wore a “South of the Border” T-shirt and conferred with director Matt Spicer on the Morris County set.

Spicer directed the 2017 dark comedy “Ingrid Goes West” starring Aubrey Plaza and Elizabeth Olsen.

Andrew Mogel and Jarrad Paul (“The D Train,” “Yes Man”) wrote the script for “Little Brother,” which was also set to film inside Nautilus Diner in Madison Friday.

The movie has also filmed in Jersey City, Bayonne, Montclair and beyond, and the production has put out a series of related casting calls for local extras.

Last week, Cena, 48, joined André to film a basketball court scene at Riverview-Fisk Park in the Jersey City Heights.

Cena, known for being a WWE star as well as a film and TV actor, was announced as a lead of “Little Brother” after WWE entered a partnership with Netflix.

André released his comedy special “Eric Andre: Legalize Everything” on Netflix in 2020 and starred in the hidden-camera road comedy “Bad Trip” on Netflix in 2021.

He also recently appeared in Netflix’s “Happy Gilmore 2″ alongside Adam Sandler.

Sandler, who filmed extensively in New Jersey last year for the Gilmore sequel, has been back in Jersey this summer filming two other Netflix movies that he’s producing through his Happy Madison production company.

One is “Roommates,” starring his daughter Sadie Sandler, 19. The other is “Don’t Say Good Luck,” starring his daughter Sunny Sandler, 16.

These are among the parade of Netflix movies that have filmed in Jersey this summer, well before the expected opening of the streamer’s planned film studio at Fort Monmouth in 2028.

Others have included “72 Hours,” a comedy starring Kevin Hart, and Lena Dunham’s “Good Sex,” a rom-com starring Natalie Portman, Mark Ruffalo, Rashida Jones, Meg Ryan and Tucker Pillsbury, also known as the singer Role Model.

Thank you for reading. Please consider supporting NJ.com with a subscription.

Amy Kuperinsky may be reached at akuperinsky@njadvancemedia.com and followed at @AmyKup on Twitter/X, @amykup.bsky.social on Bluesky and @kupamy on Instagram and Threads.
summary: Eric André, an Emmy winner and comedian, was filming scenes for the upcoming Netflix movie “Little Brother’s” in Madison, New Jersey. The film, which stars André as the chaotic little brother to John Cena's real estate agent character in the movie, has been filming across New Jersey this summer. The scenes were filmed at Greenwood Avenue and Brittin Street in Madison. On set, André's character could be seen not paying attention to the road while driving and yelling out to a group of people on the street. The movie has also been filmed in Jersey City, Bayonne, Montclair, and beyond and has put out a series of related casting calls for local extras.
shortSummary: Eric André, alongside John Cena, filmed scenes for Netflix’s “Little Brother� in New Jersey, discussing road safety and bumper stickers.

scraped_sources.text:
Natasha Lyonne popped up on a movie set in New Jersey Tuesday.
She emerged from suburban foliage like a gumshoe on a job, but we’re pretty sure it’s not because Charlie Cale is on the case.
Lyonne, who plays the truth-seeking protagonist of the Peacock series “Poker Face,” was in Montclair for “Roommates,” a Netflix film starring Adam Sandler’s daughter Sadie Sandler.
Previously dubbed “Untitled Roommates Project,” the movie is filming in New Jersey this summer with Sandler, 19, and her co-star Chloe East (“Heretic”), 24.
The extras casting agency working on the film previously told NJ Advance Media that Adam Sandler, 58, is producing the movie through his Happy Madison production company.
Chandler Levack (“I Like Movies”) is directing.
Sandler also filmed Netflix’s “Happy Gilmore 2″ in New Jersey last year.
Lyonne, 46, wearing shades and toting a white bag and water on the blazing hot day, headed to a home on Plymouth Street in Montclair where the movie was filming.
The set was just blocks away from another Netflix production: “Little Brother,“ starring Eric André and John Cena.
Last month, “Untitled Roommates Project” put out an open casting call for extras to play college students and high school students.
It’s not yet known what roles Lyonne, Sadie and East will be playing in the film, though it does seem college roommates (Sadie and East) are involved in the story.
Sadie Sandler has been appearing in her father’s movies since she was a toddler, starting with “You Don’t Mess with the Zohan” (2008).
But Sadie and her younger sister Sunny, 16, took on larger roles in the 2023 Netflix movie “You Are So Not Invited To My Bat Mitzvah,” directed by Sammi Cohen and adapted by Alison Peck from the YA novel by Amanda Stern, aka Fiona Rosenbloom. Their father also produced that film.
Sadie voiced the character Jayda in Adam Sandler’s Netflix animated film “Leo" (2023).
Like many of Sandler’s movies, “Happy Gilmore 2,” due out July 25, is a family affair, with Sunny and Sadie Sandler appearing in the film alongside their mother, Jackie Sandler.
Stories by Amy Kuperinsky

“Good Sex,” the upcoming rom-com starring Oscar winner Natalie Portman, has added even more A-listers to its cast.
Eight-time Emmy nominee Lena Dunham is the writer and director of the Netflix movie, which is filming in New Jersey.
Bonafide rom-com legend Meg Ryan (“When Harry Met Sally,” “Sleepless in Seattle,” “You’ve Got Mail”) has joined the production, which is listed as being based in Jersey City.
So has Rashida Jones and Oscar nominee Mark Ruffalo.
Tucker Pillsbury, aka the singer Role Model, will make his screen debut in the film. The casting news arrives via reports from Deadline and The Hollywood Reporter.
Portman, 43, plays Ally, 40, a New York couples therapist who has been stuck in a relationship for years when she decides to start dating again.
She meets an older man, played by Ruffalo, 57, as well as a 20-something played by Pillsbury, 28. Ryan plays Ally’s therapist in the film.
Both Portman and Dunham are producers of the movie.
Portman, an Academy Award winner for “Black Swan,” is currently starring in the Apple TV+ series “Fountain of Youth” with John Krasinski.
READ MORE: Natalie Portman and Lena Dunham’s new rom-com ‘Good Sex’ looks to film in N.J.
She also starred in Netflix’s Todd Haynes film “May December“ (2023) with Julianne Moore and Charles Melton.
Dunham, 39, the creator and star of HBO’s “Girls,” has a Netflix rom-com series, ”Too Much," starring Meg Stalter and Will Sharpe, premiering July 10.

Start your (extremely expensive) engines.
Superstar actor-comedian Kevin Hart is filming his upcoming movie in New Jersey, and if you own a luxury car, you may just qualify to become an extra. (See details below.)
Hart’s movie “72 Hours,” a Netflix film, will be in production locally in June and July.
The comedy pairs Hart, 45, with his frequent collaborator, director Tim Story.
“72 Hours” sees Hart play a 40-something executive who joins a group of 20-somethings on a three-day bachelor party after he is mistakenly added to their group chat.
The original script comes from Jersey’s Jon Hurwitz and Hayden Schlossberg, who grew up in Randolph and are known for creating the hit “Karate Kid” revival series “Cobra Kai” — which ended this year on Netflix after six seasons — as well as writing movies including the Jersey-set stoner road comedy “Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle” (2004), starring John Cho and Jersey’s own Kal Penn. The current “72 Hours” script is also co-written by Matt Mider and Kevin Burrows.
Hart and Story, the film’s director, previously worked together on the movies “Think Like a Man” (2012), “Think Like a Man Too” (2014), “Ride Along” (2014)“ and “Ride Along 2″ (2016).
Story also directed Hart’s stand-up comedy films “Kevin Hart: Laugh at My Pain” (2011), “Kevin Hart: Let Me Explain” (2013) and “Kevin Hart: What Now?” (2016).
Hart, a producer on “72 Hours,” is himself a collector of both classic and modern cars.
His most recent Netflix film was F. Gary Gray’s “Lift,” a heist comedy filmed in Northern Ireland and Italy and released in 2024.
How to apply
Interesting in working on the movie?
Grant Wilfley Casting has put out an open call for Jersey locals who own luxury cars to appear in “72 Hours” as “pedestrians.”
Here are the luxury cars they’re looking for:
- Ferrari
- Lamborghini
- Maserati
- Lotus
- Aston Martin
- Bentley
- Porsche
- BMW 7 Series
- Mercedes S/SL/CLS/G
- Audi A7/A8 series
Anyone who has a qualifying car and is interested can apply by sending the following details to 72hours@gwcnyc.com with the subject line “Luxury Cars”:
Their full name; whether or not they are a SAG member; their height, weight, clothing and shoe sizes; whether or not they are local to New Jersey or New York and age 18 or older; make, model, year and color of the car; current, clear photos of themselves (close-up and full body) and current photo of the car.

Exactly 10 years ago today — Aug. 6, 2015 — “Hamilton” opened on Broadway at the Richard Rodgers Theatre.
Lin-Manuel Miranda, the creator of the Tony and Pulitzer Prize-winning musical, led the cast in a 10th anniversary performance at the 2025 Tonys in June.
But the celebration doesn’t stop there.
This summer, “Hamilton” is headed to movie theaters for the first time.
Miranda made the announcement on “The Tonight Show” Tuesday night.
The version of the show that will be in theaters was filmed during the Broadway run in 2016 and was first released in 2020 via streaming through Disney+ over Fourth of July weekend in the thick of the early COVID-19 pandemic.
“Hamilton” won the 2021 Emmy for outstanding variety special (pre-recorded).
READ MORE: Watch original ‘Hamilton’ cast celebrate 10th anniversary of the Broadway sensation at the Tonys
But really, the musical was supposed to play on the big screen first.
“We always wanted to release it theatrically, but then the pandemic hit and so we decided to release it on streaming so that everyone could see it at home whenever they wanted,” Miranda, 45, told Jimmy Fallon.
“Hamilton” is coming to movie theaters Sept. 5. Tickets are on sale from Aug. 6.
“Turn up, sing along,” Miranda said. “We’re all going to watch ‘Hamilton.’”
In 2016, the musical sensation took home 11 Tonys, including best musical, book and score for Miranda.
Leslie Odom Jr. won the Tony for best actor in a musical for his performance of Aaron Burr in the show, while Daveed Diggs, who played the Marquis de Lafayette and Thomas Jefferson, won best featured actor in a musical and Renée Elise Goldsberry, who played Angelica Schuyler, won best featured actress in a musical.
Miranda won the 2016 Pulitzer Prize for drama for his musical, and the cast as a whole won the Grammy for best musical theater album.
West Orange’s Okieriete “Oak” Onaodowan was another standout in the show as Hercules Mulligan and James Madison.
“Hamilton” has expanded over the years with a North American tour, along with runs in the United Kingdom and Ireland, and remains at the Richard Rodgers Theatre today.
Odom is returning to the Broadway musical as Aaron Burr Sept. 9 to Nov. 26 (apart from Sept. 18).
And yes, “Hamilton” is still on Disney+.

Actor-comedian Kevin Hart is filming his next Netflix movie, and he’s doing it in New Jersey.
Producers are looking for local residents to board the production, which is filming in June.
Hart, 45, stars in the comedy “72 Hours” as a 40-something executive who is accidentally added to a group chat of 20-somethings. He ends up joining them for a three-day bachelor party — hence the 72 hours.
The production needs Jersey people who can party on land and water to play clubgoers and yacht partygoers.
See full details and how to apply to become an extra below.
The movie, produced by Hart, is directed by Tim Story, Hart’s frequent collaborator, who also directed him in “Think Like a Man” (2012), “Think Like a Man Too” (2014), “Ride Along” (2014)“ and “Ride Along 2″ (2016).
“72 Hours” is co-written by New Jersey’s Jon Hurwitz and Hayden Schlossberg, the co-creators of the popular Netflix “Karate Kid” revival series “Cobra Kai.” They both hail from Randolph and wrote “Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle” (2004).
Who can apply/how to apply
If you’re interested in becoming an extra in “72 Hours,” here are Grant Wilfley Casting’s latest casting calls for the movie.
First, the production needs people who are 18 to 35 years old to play clubgoers from June 24 to 26 in New Jersey.
To apply, email 72hours@gwcnyc.com with the subject line “CLUB” and include: your name, phone number, whether or not you are a SAG member, if you are available June 24 to 26, if you’re available for a fitting before then, your current sizes (for men, that means height, weight, suit, neck x sleeve, waist x inseam and shoe; for women, that means height, weight, bust x waist x hips, dress/pants, shoe), whether or not you have visible tattoos (and if so, where), confirmation you are at least 18 and a local tri-state resident, and current non-professional photos, including one full body photo.
Second, the production needs people to play yacht partygoers (again, 18 to 35 years old) July 14 to July 18 in New Jersey.
Anyone interested can email their information to 72hours@gwcnyc.com with the subject line “YACHT PARTY.” Include your name, whether or not you are a SAG member, whether or not you are available July 14 to 18 and available for a fitting before then, your current sizes (for men, that means height, weight, suit, neck x sleeve, waist x inseam and shoe; for women, that means height, weight, bust x waist x hips, dress/pants, shoe), whether you have an visible tattoos and where, confirmation you’re at least 18 and local to the tri-state area, if you’re OK with working on a boat and current non-professional photos, including at least one full body photo.
Earlier this month, the production put out a casting call for people who own specific luxury cars to appear in “72 Hours.”
Hart’s most recent Netflix film was “Lift,” a 2024 heist comedy directed by F. Gary Gray.

After years of planning, Netflix recently broke ground on its massive production studio planned for a 289-acre former Army base in Monmouth County.
Gov. Phil Murphy and Netflix co-CEO Ted Sarandos joined state and local officials last month to kick off the project, as a wrecking ball took its first swing to start demolition at the historic site.
The media giant has secured the local and state approvals it needs to move forward with phase one of its $903 million plan to transform the shuttered Army base into one of its largest film and television production hubs.
Here’s the latest on where the project stands and what’s still to come:
Where will the new Netflix studio be located?
Netflix won a $55 million bid in 2021 to acquire the 289-acre “mega-parcel” at Fort Monmouth, a former U.S. Army base spanning the boroughs of Oceanport and Eatontown near Route 35.
The base, originally established in 1917 as Camp Little Silver, played a key role in military communications and technology development.
It was home to several major innovations, including the development of FM radio. It was also the site of Project Diana — a 1940s experiment that successfully bounced radar signals off the Moon.
“Nearly 80 years ago, the U.S. Army worked within the halls of Fort Monmouth to send radar signals to the stars for the first time as part of Project Diana,” Gov. Phil Murphy said at the Netflix studio groundbreaking in May. “Soon, Netflix will work within these same walls to capture and send stars of a different variety into the homes and screens of millions of viewers around the world.”
Fort Monmouth officially closed in 2011. More than 5,000 civilian and military jobs relocated to an Army base in Maryland.
The property includes several historic, protected sites like the parade grounds, World War II Memorial and Cowan Park, all of which must be preserved during development, according to officials.
What is Netflix building at Fort Monmouth?
Netflix wants to transform Fort Monmouth into a state-of-the-art film and television production campus.
The $903 million project includes 12 soundstages totaling nearly 500,000 square feet, along with production and office buildings.
A hotel, cafeteria, helipad, theater, retail shops, studio trailer parks, water tanks for aquatic filming and visitor attractions are also planned.
According to recent site plans, the infrastructure will include new roads, sidewalks, landscaping and stormwater systems. And the entire campus will be enclosed by a precast concrete wall monitored by security.
The studio is expected to be one of Netflix’s largest, similar to the company’s 300-acre facility in Albuquerque, New Mexico, Netflix officials previously told NJ Advance Media.
When will it be finished?
Demolition at Fort Monmouth began May 2025 following the ceremonial groundbreaking, marking the start of a 13-month teardown of the aging Army buildings.
Once demolition is complete, construction will move forward in two phases over the next few years.
Phase one will focus on the 29-acre McAfee Zone, which spans Oceanport and about three acres of Eatontown. The area includes the 90,000-square-foot McAfee Center and a 1965 bowling alley, both slated for demolition. In total, 15 buildings will be cleared to make way for new facilities.
The first phase of construction includes building four soundstages, converting the McAfee Center into studio offices and production support space, and constructing a warehouse and mill building.
The buildings will not be open to the public and are intended for cast, crew and studio operations, according to planning documents.
Phase two will include building the remaining eight soundstages, more production and office buildings, and visitor attractions.
Under terms set by the Fort Monmouth Economic Revitalization Authority, the agency overseeing the site’s redevelopment, both phases must be completed within eight years of the land deal’s closing.
Netflix expects the entire production campus to be finished by 2028, officials said.
Who has approved the plan so far?
Since announcing its proposal to build a production campus at Fort Monmouth, Netflix has received several key approvals at the state and local level.
The first major approval came from the Fort Monmouth Economic Revitalization Authority in February 2024.
Following a 45-day public comment period, the authority unanimously approved an amendment establishing zoning for the project, allowing the base to be reused as a studio under Netflix’s plans.
The initial reuse plans were also signed off by Gov. Phil Murphy.
By the end of 2024, both Jersey Shore towns where the studio will be located, Oceanport and Eatontown, approved Netflix’s phase one site plans.
A second application, covering the remainder of the campus, will go before the Eatontown Planning Board in August.
Are there any concerns about Netflix’s plans?
Murphy and other state officials have been vocal supporters of Netflix’s planned production hub, calling it a catalyst for making New Jersey “the future of entertainment.”
Still, there have been some local-level concerns throughout the approval process.
Public meetings leading up to state and municipal sign-offs revealed a range of community worries, including traffic congestion, construction noise, building aesthetics and the potential impact on nearby wetlands.
Some residents questioned whether the development would strain local emergency services. Others criticized Netflix’s plan for a concrete perimeter wall, with one Oceanport planning board member saying it clashed with Fort Monmouth’s historic character and should be built with brick instead.
Despite the concerns, the project continues to advance, with Netflix and state officials highlighting its potential to create thousands of jobs and generate billions for New Jersey’s economy.
Is the Netflix studio getting any tax breaks?
Netflix is set to receive hundreds of millions in tax breaks as part of its plan to build a production studio on Fort Monmouth.
The company will have access to a $150 million pool of incentives and a potential 40% tax credit through New Jersey’s Film and Digital Media Tax Credit program, according to the state Economic Development Authority.
It has also been approved for up to $387 million in tax credits under the authority’s Aspire program, which supports large-scale development projects with long-term economic benefits. In exchange, Netflix has committed to operating the studio in New Jersey for at least 10 years.
According to state officials, the production campus will create more than 3,500 construction jobs and employ about 1,400 people once operational.
Over 20 years, the studio is projected to contribute between $3.8 billion and $4.6 billion to New Jersey’s economy, state officials said.
At the groundbreaking last month, Murphy said “good-paying jobs are soon to follow” as construction begins.
“As we begin building the 12 state-of-the-art soundstages that will anchor this facility, we’ll rely on New Jersey’s construction workers to get the job done,” Murphy said.
Stories by Nyah Marshall
Our journalism needs your support. Please subscribe today to NJ.com.
Nyah Marshall may be reached at nmarshall@njadvancemedia.com

Happy Gilmore has an anger problem.
It’s what makes the famously quick-tempered hockey enthusiast-turned-golfer the star he is.
Adam Sandler’s “Happy Gilmore,” released in 1996, is one of his celebrated movies about how red-hot rage, when channeled productively, can lead to greatness — and great comedy. (Another example is “The Waterboy” from 1998.)
“I always power my drives the old-fashioned way — with rage," Gilmore says in the sequel “Happy Gilmore 2,” arriving on Netflix Friday (July 25).
But with the explosive Gilmore safely ensconced in middle age, content with his marriage, his big family and his career as a pro golfer, it makes sense for him to ask his wife, Virginia Venit, if he should retire from the sport.
Because while life can supply an endless stream of irritations, Gilmore is generally at ease at the start of “Happy Gilmore 2.”
However, the sequel, arriving almost 30 years after the first movie, doesn’t let Happy enjoy that peace for much longer.
A great tragedy, which will remain nameless here (no spoiler!), blows up his world. Golf is banished from his life. All he wants to do is numb the pain with alcohol. Household objects, golf equipment and produce — remote control, golf ball, cucumber — are all just flasks in disguise that feed his habit.
As Gilmore approaches rock bottom, desperation and depression cloud his usual rage.
Where will Happy work it all out?
New Jersey, of course.
Sandler, who has become a Jersey regular while filming various Netflix movies on local streets, spent last fall making “Happy Gilmore 2″ here with director Kyle Newacheck.
“My goodness, you have some beautiful golf courses out there in New Jersey,” Newacheck tells NJ Advance Media.
The movie filmed extensively in Jersey — nine counties total — with golf action happening at nine Garden State greens and driving ranges in Bergen, Essex, Monmouth, Morris, Somerset and Warren counties (see county-by-county list of film locations below).
Gilmore also practices his swing in places like Ideal Beach in Middletown.
Another kind of Jersey landmark impressed Newacheck.
“Your airport: fan-tastic,” he says.
Newark Liberty International Airport is home to what the director describes as “a big airplane joke” in the film.
“Everybody was really cool and it looked great,” he says.
The state Economic Development Authority tells NJ Advance Media that the production spent $152 million in New Jersey, receiving a $62.5 million tax credit.
Newacheck, 41, started scouting locations for the film last summer.
“I really liked some old buildings we shot in,” he says. “My only complaint is how humid it was when I was walking around scouting. I mean, it’s not even really a complaint. I just remember that my entire being was covered in sweat, and I wasn’t used to that feeling.”
Newacheck, who hails from California, is one of the creators and stars of the Comedy Central series “Workaholics.” He previously directed Sandler in the 2019 Netflix movie “Murder Mystery,” co-starring Jennifer Aniston. He was also a director and producer on the FX comedy series “What We Do in the Shadows.”
Sandler, now 58, filmed the first “Happy Gilmore” when he was in his late 20s and still at the beginning of his movie career. Arriving not long after the 1995 box office success of “Billy Madison,“ the film strengthened his presence as a lead in film comedies. The irascible Gilmore charmed Sandler’s growing fanbase.
“I think he hit a main vein,” Newacheck says of the film’s enduring popularity. “Sometimes there’s these projects that speak to people on a level that is almost unexplainable. But I believe that this one is because people love the character of Happy Gilmore. People love the bad boy that entered golf 30 years ago. That fish-out-of-water story was truly hilarious.
“The scene when he comes in to the country club wearing his, like, sleeveless Aerosmith shirt and then juxtaposed against all of the gold jackets and the hoity-toity, the nose-up snobbery of golf, I think that made Adam Sandler the people’s champ,” he says. “Somehow that just started him on his way to being the most relatable main character that’s out there.”
Adam Sandler: Everyman
Sandler gives Gilmore a lovable, rough-around-the-edges quality.
“I think there is a real element of Adam himself who remains an everyman somehow,” Newacheck says of the comedy giant, who has a reported $250 million deal with Netflix, having first linked up with the streamer in 2014.
The filmmaker says Gilmore’s “he feels just like me” vibe remains at the heart of Happy, even when he’s made it to the pinnacle of his sport.
“I think when it comes to Happy Gilmore, the character, it’s really interesting because simultaneously, you have a golf superhero who essentially can hit the ball longer than anybody and he’s just naturally talented,” Newacheck says. “You have a golf superhero and an underdog ... who people love rooting for to make it ... So you’re getting the best of both worlds with this character.”
When “Happy Gilmore 2″ put out casting calls for local background actors and extras, people jumped at the chance to be in the sequel. And when Sandler posted a photo of Gilmore’s Boston Bruins jersey on a hanger in September, fans ate it up.
Years of rewatches and new generations discovering Gilmore have given the sequel a potent nostalgia push.
Anticipation for Happy’s comeback “makes the stakes high,” Newacheck says.
Working with an established character like Gilmore “provides its own challenge, knowing that OK, we need to make something that is comparable to (the first movie), and this has 30 years of love cooked into it,” the director says. “But there’s also the other side of that, which is ‘hey, this has 30 years of love cooked into it. They love this guy.’ So we’re starting with a little bit of a leg up, I guess."
As with the first “Happy Gilmore,” which was directed by Dennis Dugan, Sandler co-wrote the sequel with fellow “Saturday Night Live” alum Tim Herlihy, his collaborator since they were roommates at New York University.
“I think he felt pressure,” Newacheck says of Sandler’s return to Gilmore.
“How many pieces of art are out there that are 30 years in the making at this level of cultural relevance? ... It’s up on pedestal. You know, there’s a ‘we gotta do this right.’ There’s a pressure. But I believe that Sandler works great under pressure ... He didn’t have to make this movie. He wouldn’t have made it unless it was the right time to make this movie and the right story to support the character.”
Callbacks to 1996, returning cast and real family
In this latest chapter, Happy Gilmore can’t wallow in his own self-destruction for too long.
As with the first movie, he finds his motivation in trying to get money to help a loved one (in the original film, it is his grandmother, who is about to lose her home).
He starts the sequel riding high from his long and successful golf career, but after a series of unfortunate incidents, he loses almost all of his money.
His daughter, Vienna, played by Sandler’s real teen daughter Sunny Sandler, is excelling in ballet and has a chance at attending a prestigious ballet school in Paris. But Gilmore will have to come up with the money to send her there.
He rallies to make a return to golf, which comes with a comically rich readjustment period.
With Gilmore, it always seems to be one step forward, three steps back — especially when he mixes alcohol with his volatility on the golf course and that tendency to fly off the handle.
“In this movie, he’s got a whole bunch of new flaws that he has to fight through,” Newacheck says.
For every one of those flaws, there are seemingly tenfold familiar faces that show up in the movie.
Emmy winner Julie Bowen (“Modern Family”) returns as Happy’s love Virginia Venit, Christopher McDonald is back as Happy’s original nemesis, golf pro Shooter McGavin, and Ben Stiller returns as the dastardly, mustachioed Hal L., who cooks up yet another self-serving scheme.
READ MORE: Hole-in-one? ‘Happy Gilmore 2,’ filmed in N.J., breaks Netflix and Adam Sandler records.
There are flashbacks to the first film and callbacks to famous lines (“I eat pieces of sh-- like you for breakfast,” “You eat pieces of sh-- for breakfast?” and “You’re in my world now, Grandma”). Gilmore tries to call upon the original movie’s lessons to guide him back to the game that brought him glory.
The sequel takes time to remember “Gilmore” stars who are no longer with us, including Bob Barker (“The price is wrong, b----!”) and Carl Weathers, who played Happy’s mentor Chubbs Peterson (“It’s all in the hips”).
This time, Sandler spotlights his family, who has appeared in many of his films since the Gilmore days. His daughters have taken on major roles in movies he’s produced in recent years (“You Are So Not Invited To My Bat Mitzvah,” plus two films currently in production in New Jersey via his Happy Madison Productions).
In addition to Sunny Sandler, 16, who plays Gilmore’s daughter Vienna, his other daughter Sadie Sandler, 19, plays a character who encourages Happy on his comeback journey. Sandler’s wife, Jackie Sandler, is Vienna’s ballet teacher.
“The truth in what they’re saying to each other comes out a little bit more naturally because they’ve already spent so much time with each other,” Newacheck says of the Sandlers. “They know each other inside and out. That chemistry is something that is very hard to find, chemistry that works on screen with strangers. With Sunny and Adam, the chemistry is there.”
Gilmore also has four grown sons — Terry (Conor Sherry), Wayne (Ethan Cutkosky of “Shameless”), Gordie (professional wrestler Maxwell Jacob Friedman) and Bobby (Philip Schneider) — a raucous bunch who definitely inherited his propensity for explosive rage and brawling.
New to Gilmore’s nemesis roster is actor-director Benny Safdie (“Oppenheimer,” “Uncut Gems”).
He plays Frank Manatee, president of Maxi Golf, a new, rival league with a secret weapon that grants players Gilmore-like power. Manatee tries to court Gilmore to join him and turn against his fellow golden-jacketed golf champions.
Among Manatee’s recruits: a golfer played by Haley Joel Osment.
An ensuing golf tournament, choreographed with flashy obstacles, turns the sport into an event that might have more in common with “American Ninja Warrior” and “Wipeout.” Gilmore finds himself on a quest to save the soul of golf.
More Jersey locations in the movie include the former Essex County Isolation Hospital/Soho Hospital in Belleville (Arkham State Hospital in “Joker: Folie à Deux”), as well as Stop & Shop in Clifton Commons.
Gilmore, who takes a job at the supermarket, hurls the appropriately named Manatee into the seafood department’s lobster tank.
When the production was not shooting on location, scenes were filmed at Sustainable Studios in Moonachie.
The exterior of Gilmore’s house was filmed in Irvington. A Belleville house played the interior. There, professional golfer John Daly seems especially at home in Sandler’s world, having shacked up with Gilmore and his family in the movie.
“Happy Gilmore 2″ brings plentiful cameos from other pro golfers past and present, like Jack Nicklaus, Rory McIlroy, Brooks Koepka, Nelly Korda, Paige Spiranac and Collin Morikawa.
Lest anyone should accuse the film of not being golf-centered, there’s even more: Tony Finau, Will Zalatoris, Nancy Lopez, Bubba Watson, Rickie Fowler, Justin Thomas, Scottie Scheffler and Bryson DeChambeau.
The Sandlerverse and celebrity casting
Who else is in “Happy Gilmore 2″?
A more useful question might be “who isn’t in ‘Happy Gilmore 2′?“
The huge cast sees actors from the Happyverse and wider Sandlerverse — Steve Buscemi, Jon Lovitz, Lavell Crawford, Kevin Nealon, Blake Clark, Kym Whitley, Rob Schneider, Nick Swardson, Oliver Hudson and John Farley (brother of Chris) — meet pop-ins from music superstars like Eminem (in a wig for a standout role as a new heckler), Kid Cudi, aka Scott Mescudi, and Post Malone, aka Austin Post.
Global megastar Bad Bunny, aka Benito Antonio Martínez Ocasio, has the most screen time of that group as Oscar Mejias, a waiter who Gilmore recruits to be his caddie.
Mejias has his own nemesis in the form of a fellow waiter played by Kansas City Chiefs tight end Travis Kelce, plus memorable support onscreen from “SNL” star Marcello Hernandez.
Basketball player Boban Marjanović, who stands at 7-foot-4, plays the son of Mr. Larson, who was played by the late Richard Kiel (7-foot-1) in the original film.
Retired sportscaster Verne Lundquist returns from the first movie to play himself, and is joined by others from sports media including Stephen A. Smith, Dan Patrick and former NFL star Reggie Bush.
“Jeopardy” host Ken Jennings, Flavortown’s own Guy Fieri and “Hot Ones” host Sean Evans are in the mix, too. Rapper Cam’ron is seen in his podcasting element. So is New Jersey social media influencer Alix Earle. Joining Friedman in the professional wrestler category are Nikki Garcia (Nikki Bella) and Becky Lynch.
READ MORE: In ‘Happy Gilmore 2,’ Adam Sandler remembers Disney Channel star Cameron Boyce, who played his son
The “Happy Gilmore” legacy passes from co-writer Tim Herlihy to his son, Emmy-nominated “Saturday Night Live” writer and star Martin Herlihy, a member of the comedy group Please Don’t Destroy.
Both Herlihys make appearances in the sequel, Martin as a member of a golf trio alongside Emmy-nominated “The Substance” star Margaret Qualley and Eric André, the Emmy-winning host of Adult Swim’s “The Eric André Show.”
As Qualley previously shared with late-night host Jimmy Fallon, she didn’t have any experience golfing, despite what her husband, (New Jersey’s own) Grammy-winning producer Jack Antonoff, told Sandler when he asked.
But as an ardent “Gilmore” and Sandler fan, she was desperate to be in the film, in any capacity.
“Working with Margaret was awesome,” Newacheck says.
When she came to set, she told him she didn’t really do improv or comedy.
“I was like ‘well, we’re doing four days of almost pure improv,’” the director says.
“We were really playing around in that sequence to find the funny, and we were very frenetic. It was a very jazz-like sequence when we were making it ... She brought so much to that sequence, and I was just really proud of her for doing that. It was so cool, it’s awesome to watch.”
In one scene, Qualley, who is also a trained ballet dancer, busts out a split on the golf course.
“Everybody kind of has a story like that,” Newacheck says of the “Gilmore” cast. “People were there for a couple days and then they would leave ... It was just a revolving door of people who wanted to hang out and give the best they could to the movie.”
See a full list of “Happy Gilmore 2″ Jersey film locations below.
“Happy Gilmore 2,″ rated PG-13, runs 1 hour and 54 minutes and will be released on Netflix Friday, July 25 (3 a.m. ET, midnight PT).

The mockumentary universe that gave us “The Office” is one step closer to its return.
A trailer for Peacock’s “The Paper” (watch below) gives a window into what life is like at the Toledo Truth Teller, the setting for a workplace comedy follow-up to the hit NBC series.
While Emmy-winning “The Office” was set at Dunder Mifflin, a paper company, the new show, premiering in September (see tune-in information below), is set at an Ohio newspaper.
“Several years ago, a documentary crew filmed the story of Dunder Mifflin,” the trailer begins. “Now they’ve found a new subject.”
The Toledo Truth Teller, like many newspapers, struggles under the weight of the loss of ad revenue to Google and the dominance of free information on the internet.
Enter Ned Sampson, a new editor-in-chief played by Irish actor Domhnall Gleeson.
READ MORE: ‘The Office’ sequel ‘The Paper’ gets premiere date. Series favorite from N.J. among cast.
He admits that the Truth Teller “sucks,” but vows that he and the staff will “make it better.”
To that end, Sampson hires a group of new reporters who have no reporting experience.
One face that viewers will be particularly familiar with among the cast is New Jersey’s Oscar Nuñez, who played Oscar Martinez in all nine seasons of “The Office" (2005 to 2013).
Nuñez, who grew up in Union City, reprises the character in the Peacock series.
And Martinez is not happy about the film crew in his new office.
“Not again,” he says in the trailer, eyeing the mockumentary cameras. “I’m not agreeing to any of this.”
“I will make this unusable,” he tells the crew.
“F---,” he says in a bleeped-out moment. “Use that.”
Martinez, who was an accountant at Dunder Mifflin, had become a state senator in Pennsylvania by the end of “The Office.”
Peacock released both the trailer and a series of images from “The Paper” Wednesday.
“The Paper” comes from Greg Daniels, who developed “The Office” as an adaptation of the British series of the same name. Daniels is series creator, writer and executive producer alongside Michael Koman (“Nathan For You”).
Ricky Gervais and Stephen Merchant, who created the original “The Office,” serve as executive producers of “The Paper.”
Besides Gleeson and Nuñez, the show stars Sabrina Impacciatore, an Italian actor known for her Emmy-nominated performance in HBO’s “The White Lotus.”
Also in the cast: Emmy and Tony-winning comedian Alex Edelman; Chelsei Frei (“Poker Face”); Melvin Gregg (“Snowfall”); Gbemisola Ikumelo (“A League of Their Own”); Ramona Young (“Santa Clarita Diet”); and Tim Key (“The Witchfinder”).
The first four episodes of “The Paper” premiere on Peacock Sept. 4. After that, two episodes will be released each Thursday through Sept. 25.
The lineup of guest stars to come in the show includes the Pulitzer Prize and Tony-winning playwright Tracy Letts (“Homeland”), Duane Shepard Sr. (“The Eric Andre Show”), Molly Ephraim (“Perry Mason”), Nate Jackson (“Curb Your Enthusiasm”), Allan Havey (“Billions”), Nancy Lenehan (“The Boys”), Mo Welch (“Corporate”) and Eric Rahill (“Friendship”).
Stories by Amy Kuperinsky

Entertainment
23 January 2024Long-Term Deal Brings Weekly Live Sports Entertainment to Netflix
STAMFORD, Conn., January 23, 2024 – WWE, part of TKO Group Holdings, Inc. (NYSE: TKO), and Netflix (NASDAQ: NFLX) today announced a long-term partnership that will bring WWE’s flagship weekly program – Raw – to the world’s leading entertainment service. This marks a major programming shift as Raw leaves linear television for the first time since its inception 31 years ago. Beginning in January 2025, Netflix will be the exclusive new home of Raw in the U.S., Canada, U.K. and Latin America, among other territories, with additional countries and regions to be added over time. Likewise, as part of the agreement, Netflix will also become the home for all WWE shows and specials outside the U.S. as available, inclusive of Raw and WWE’s other weekly shows – SmackDown and NXT – as well as the company’s Premium Live Events, including WrestleMania, SummerSlam and Royal Rumble. WWE’s award-winning documentaries, original series and forthcoming projects will also be available on Netflix internationally beginning in 2025. “This deal is transformative,” said Mark Shapiro, TKO President and COO. “It marries the can’t-miss WWE product with Netflix’s extraordinary global reach and locks in significant and predictable economics for many years. Our partnership fundamentally alters and strengthens the media landscape, dramatically expands the reach of WWE, and brings weekly live appointment viewing to Netflix.” “We are excited to have WWE Raw, with its huge and passionate multigenerational fan base, on Netflix,” said Netflix Chief Content Officer, Bela Bajaria. “By combining our reach, recommendations, and fandom with WWE, we’ll be able to deliver more joy and value for their audiences and our members. Raw is the best of sports entertainment, blending great characters and storytelling with live action 52 weeks a year and we’re thrilled to be in this long-term partnership with WWE.” “In its relatively short history, Netflix has engineered a phenomenal track record for storytelling,” said Nick Khan, WWE President. “We believe Netflix, as one of the world’s leading entertainment brands, is the ideal long-term home for Raw’s live, loyal, and ever-growing fan base." With 1600 episodes to date, Raw is the most iconic show in sports entertainment. Since its debut in 1993, Raw has delivered action, compelling drama and unmatched athleticism – 52 weeks a year. Blending the best of scripted content with unpredictable live entertainment, the three-hour show has helped launch the careers of Dwayne “The Rock” Johnson, “Stone Cold” Steve Austin, Triple H, John Cena, Roman Reigns, Bianca Belair and Charlotte Flair. The show is currently the No. 1 show on USA Network, where it brings in 17.5 million unique viewers over the course of the year. One of television’s best performing shows in the 18-49 advertising demographic, Raw trends on X 52 weeks a year while each new episode is airing. On social media, WWE has more than one billion followers across its platforms.
# # #
About WWE WWE, part of TKO Group Holdings (NYSE: TKO), is an integrated media organization and the recognized global leader in sports entertainment. The company consists of a portfolio of businesses that create and deliver original content 52 weeks a year to a global audience. WWE is committed to family-friendly entertainment on its television programming, premium live events, digital media, and publishing platforms. WWE’s TV-PG programming can be seen in more than 1 billion homes worldwide in 25 languages through world-class distribution partners including NBCUniversal, FOX Sports, TNT Sport, Sony India and Rogers. The award-winning WWE Network includes all premium live events, scheduled programming and a massive video-on-demand library and is currently available in approximately 165 countries. In the United States, NBCUniversal’s streaming service, Peacock, is the exclusive home to WWE Network. Additional information on WWE can be found at wwe.com and corporate.wwe.com.
About Netflix Netflix is one of the world's leading entertainment services with over 247 million paid memberships in over 190 countries enjoying TV series, films and games across a wide variety of genres and languages. Members can play, pause and resume watching as much as they want, anytime, anywhere, and can change their plans at any time.
About TKO TKO Group Holdings, Inc. (NYSE: TKO) is a premium sports and entertainment company that comprises UFC, the world’s premier mixed martial arts organization, and WWE, an integrated media organization and the recognized global leader in sports entertainment. Together, our organizations reach more than 1 billion TV households in approximately 170 countries, and we organize more than 350 live events year-round, attracting over one million fans. TKO is majority owned by Endeavor Group Holdings, Inc. (NYSE: EDR), a global sports and entertainment company.
Forward-Looking Statements This press release contains forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 intended to be covered by the safe harbor provisions contained in Section 27A of the Securities Act of 1933, as amended, and Section 21E of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended. All statements in this press release that do not relate to matters of historical fact should be considered forward-looking statements, including, without limitation, expected programming and viewer benefits under the multi-year domestic media rights partnership with and NBCUniversal. These statements are neither promises nor guarantees and involve known and unknown risks, uncertainties that may cause actual results, performance or achievements to be materially different from what is expressed or implied by the forward-looking statements, including, but not limited to the factors discussed in the section entitled “Risk Factors” in TKO’s final prospectus on Form 424(b)(3) filed with the SEC on September 19, 2023, as any such factors may be updated from time to time. Forward-looking statements speak only as of the date they are made and, except as may be required under applicable law, neither TKO nor WWE undertake any obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
Investors and others should note that TKO announces material financial and operational information to its investors using press releases, SEC filings and public conference calls and webcasts, as well as its Investor Relations site at investor.tkogrp.com. TKO may also use its website as a distribution channel of material information about the Company. In addition, you may automatically receive email alerts and other information about TKO, UFC and WWE when you enroll your email address by visiting the “Investor Email Alerts” option under the Resources tab on investor.tkogrp.com.

Eric André and John Cena are brothers in an upcoming Netflix movie filming in New Jersey.
Production on “Little Brother” is underway locally, with the latest scenes scheduled to film Tuesday in Montclair.
The movie revolves around a prominent real estate agent, played by Cena, and his younger brother, played by André.
Everything in the professional’s life is turned upside down when his little brother shows up.
Matt Spicer, director of the 2017 dark comedy “Ingrid Goes West,” is helming the film, written by Jarrad Paul and Andrew Mogel (“The D Train,” “Yes Man”).
Spicer’s involvement in “Little Brother” was first announced in April after word of the movie surfaced in December.
Casting calls have been posted for background actors and extras in New Jersey and New York.
The production is filming in Montclair the same day (Tuesday, July 8) as the Adam Sandler-produced Netflix movie starring his daughter Sadie Sandler.
READ MORE: Adam Sandler is making another movie in N.J. with his daughter. See local casting call.
That film is currently known as “Untitled Roommates Project.” (Last month, the production put a call out for extras to play college students and high school students.)
André, 42, also appears in Adam Sandler’s “Happy Gilmore 2,” which filmed in New Jersey last year and will be released on Netflix July 25.
André, host of “The Eric André Show” on Adult Swim since 2012, won his first Emmy last year for the series, some of which he filmed in Jersey. His comedy special “Eric Andre: Legalize Everything” debuted on Netflix in 2020.
He has starred in films including Netflix’s hidden-camera road comedy “Bad Trip” (2021), alongside Lil Rel Howery, and voiced the hyena Azizi in Disney’s 2019 remake of “The Lion King.”
Cena, 48, a star in the WWE with many acting roles to his name, was linked to “Little Brother” months after news of WWE’s impending partnership with Netflix, which started this year. The professional wrestler and actor most recently appeared with Idris Elba, Priyanka Chopra and more in the Amazon film “Heads of State,” an action comedy released July 2.
READ MORE: N.J.-filmed ‘Happy Gilmore 2’ is nearly here. Adam Sandler’s Netflix sequel gets full trailer.
“Ingrid Goes West,” Spicer’s feature directorial debut, stars Aubrey Plaza and Elizabeth Olsen.
The movie is about a woman named Ingrid (Plaza) who develops a fixation on Taylor, an Instagram influencer (Olsen). She proceeds to move across the country to Los Angeles and stalk her life, scheming to befriend Taylor.
The film won the Independent Spirit Award for best first feature and the Waldo Salt Screenwriting Award at the Sundance Film Festival (Spicer co-wrote the film with David Branson Smith).

Adam Sandler’s “Happy Gilmore 2″ is headed to Netflix in July, but before then, he’s working on another movie filming in New Jersey.
Sandler, who filmed extensively in the Garden State for his celebrity-packed golf comedy sequel, apparently liked being here so much he decided to go another round.
The actor and comedian is producing a Netflix film starring his teen daughter Sadie Sandler.
The untitled film, currently known as “Untitled Roommates Project,” is going into production this summer and looking for New Jersey extras and background actors.
Grant Wilfley Casting tells NJ Advance Media that the production needs people to play college and high school students.
The comedy, which is filming in Jersey from late June to August, will be directed by Chandler Levack (“I Like Movies”) and star Sadie Sandler, 19, and Chloe East, 24.
East had a memorable role playing Sister Paxton in the intense 2024 horror film “Heretic” alongside Sophie Thatcher and Hugh Grant. She also appeared in Steven Spielberg’s “The Fabelmans” (2022).
READ MORE: N.J.-filmed ‘Happy Gilmore 2’ is nearly here. Adam Sandler’s Netflix sequel gets full trailer.
Adam Sandler, 58, is producing the “Untitled Roommates Project” through his company Happy Madison Productions.
Sadie Sandler also appears in “Happy Gilmore 2″ with her sister Sunny Sandler and mother Jackie Sandler.
The Sandler sisters appear in many of their father’s films, but have increasingly been stepping into the spotlight with starring roles.
Both Sadie and Sunny, 16, starred in the 2023 Netflix movie “You Are So Not Invited To My Bat Mitzvah,” written by Alison Peck (based on the YA novel by Amanda Stern, writing as Fiona Rosenbloom) and directed by Sammi Cohen.
Adam Sandler produced the well-received comedy.
How to apply to be an extra
Extras have to be 18 or older (and can play younger in the movie).
If you want to apply to play a college student or high school student in the film, email roommates@gwcnyc.com with the subject “College Students” or “High School Students.”
Include your name; phone number; confirmation that you are 18 and local to New Jersey; whether or not you are a Screen Actors Guild member; whether or not you have any visible tattoos; height, weight and clothing sizes (for costumes); and clear, current photos of yourself.
The SAG rate for background actors is $216 per eight hours until July 1, then $224 per eight hours after that date. Non-SAG actors: $176 per 10 hours.

Natalie Portman is starring in Lena Dunham’s upcoming romantic comedy film “Good Sex.”
Deadline reports that Netflix is picking up the movie and that the production is looking to film in New Jersey.
Golden Globe winner Dunham, 38, creator of the HBO series “Girls,” wrote the script and will direct the film.
Both Dunham and Oscar winner Portman (“Black Swan”), 43, are producing.
Per the report, Portman will play Ally, a New York couples therapist who leaves a dying long-term relationship to start dating again.
She makes a connection with a younger man and meets an older man at the same time.
Netflix is reportedly shelling out somewhere around $55 million for the film.
The New Jersey Economic Development Authority tells NJ Advance Media it does not have any information yet on the production filming in New Jersey.
Dunham, who wrote and starred in the Emmy-winning “Girls,” appeared in the 2024 film “Treasure,” while Portman starred in the 2024 Apple TV+ limited series “Lady in the Lake.” Newly minted Oscar winner Mikey Madison, who won best actress for “Anora” Sunday, was one of Portman’s co-stars in the show.
Portman also starred with Julianne Moore and Charles Melton in the 2023 Todd Haynes Netflix movie “May December‚" a film about a couple with a significant age gap who met when the man (Melton) was a 13-year-old child and the woman (Moore) was 36. Portman plays an actor who meets with them to play Moore’s character in a movie.

Nathan Lane was already the pride of New Jersey.
The Emmy winner and three-time Tony winner, who grew up in Jersey City, has been giving us delightful performances on stage and screen for decades.
So when he showed up at a local student production of “Shrek the Musical” and greeted the cast with glowing compliments, it was the ultimate endorsement.
Lane was a special guest at the Sunday, Aug. 3 performance of the musical at BergenPAC in Englewood.
The actor headed backstage after the show to meet performers from BergenPAC Performing Arts School.
“I wanted to say how great all of you were, you really let your freak flag fly and it was a spectacular performance,” Lane, 69, told the actors (see video below). “Really, all of you were just tremendous. Thank you for a great afternoon.”
Lane, who attended the musical with his husband, Devlin Elliott, shook hands with Wood-Ridge’s Adam Lucas, 22, who starred as Shrek.
He also greeted Angelina Brennen, who played Fiona, and Feriz Sulejmani, who played Lord Farquaad. Brennan embraced Lane, who told her she has a “gorgeous voice.”
“It was one of those beautiful moments,” BergenPAC executive director Alexander Diaz tells NJ Advance Media of Lane’s visit.
And no, the actor didn’t pick this student musical at random.
He has a family tie to BergenPAC.
His niece, Kirsten Lane, who served as the choreographer for the show, been a faculty member in dance at BergenPAC Performing Arts School for 20 years. She trained as a ballet dancer at the School of American Ballet and performed with the New York City Ballet.
“She actually just celebrated her 20-year anniversary with us,” says Diaz, who directed the “Shrek” musical.
It was the first time her famous uncle attended a BergenPAC production.
“She invited him to the show,” Diaz says. “We were fortunate enough and lucky enough that he was free and he wanted to come see the show.”
“Kirsten’s father, who’s Nathan’s brother, on Thursday (July 31) came to the show and he was blown away by it. And we chatted in the lobby in intermission and he says ‘I’m gonna tell my brother, he has to come. He has to come.’”
The morning of the show that Sunday, Diaz learned from Kirsten Lane that her uncle would be attending.
That’s how the BergenPAC director introduced the actor to the cast at the end of “Shrek the Musical” — “Kirsten’s uncle.”
“The show was great, it was phenomenal,” Diaz says. “The experience for the students was amazing. So this was the icing on the cake on the final performance to have him in the audience and not just sit there as an uncle, but as Broadway royalty. It was a standing ovation at the end, and he was up there clapping and smiling. And his husband actually had his phone out and he was filming the finale and the standing ovation with a big smile on his face. So they clearly enjoyed being at the theater that afternoon.”
Nathan Lane, born Joseph Lane, made his Broadway debut in the play “Present Laughter” in 1982.
The Jersey actor, who had attended St. Peter’s Prep in Jersey City, won his first Tony in 1996 (best actor in a musical) for playing Pseudolus in “A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum,” his second in 2001 for playing Max Bialystock in “The Producers” and his third in 2018 (best featured actor in a play) for playing Roy Cohn in “Angels in America.”
In 2022, Lane won an Emmy for outstanding guest actor in a comedy series for playing Teddy Dimas in the Hulu series “Only Murders in the Building.”
Lane, who reprised the role of Bialystock in the 2005 film “The Producers,” is also known for other big-screen roles, including the unforgettable Albert Goldman in “The Birdcage” (1996) and Timon the meerkat in “The Lion King” (1994).
“He is so cross-generational,” Diaz says of Lane — everyone in the cast knew who he was, whatever their age.
“For him to take the time and kind of just address the work that went into this payoff ... as somebody who has performed and understands the process — to hear from him how much he enjoyed the show and the production, and what a lovely afternoon at the theater he had, I don’t think it gets any better than that coming from somebody like him."
Lane’s other TV credits include series like ABC’s “Modern Family,” FX’s “The People v. O.J. Simpson: American Crime Story,” Showtime’s “Penny Dreadful: City of Angels,” HBO’s “The Gilded Age” and Netflix’s “Monsters: The Lyle and Erik Menendez Story.”
He currently stars as Bunny Schneiderman in the Hulu comedy series “Mid-Century Modern,” which debuted in March. He’s also a producer on the show.
BergenPAC Performing Arts School has served as an early stage for performers like Clifton’s Rachel Zegler, the ascendant star and formidable singer who is currently earning raves on London’s West End as Eva Perón in “Evita.”
Before Zegler made her film debut as Maria in Steven Spielberg’s “West Side Story” in 2021, she played the same role in a 2017 BergenPAC Performing Arts School production of the musical.
The graduate of Lodi’s Immaculate Conception High School would go on to win a Golden Globe for her performance in the Spielberg movie.
Zegler, 24, also played the musical lead in the 2023 “Hunger Games” movie “The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes,” made her Broadway debut in “Romeo + Juliet” in 2024 and starred in Disney’s 2025 reimagining of “Snow White.”
Stories by Amy Kuperinsky

argos_summary: Eric André is currently filming the Netflix movie "Little Brother" in New Jersey, where he stars alongside John Cena. The film, directed by Matt Spicer, follows a chaotic younger brother, played by André, who disrupts Cena's character's life as a real estate agent. The production is part of a series of Netflix films being shot in the state, including Adam Sandler's "Happy Gilmore 2" and the "Untitled Roommates Project" featuring Sandler's daughter, Sadie. Additionally, Nathan Lane recently attended a local student production of "Shrek the Musical," where he praised the cast, highlighting his family connection to the performance.
